panels.description: This will turn red when your system needs to be rebooted because of security updates.
panels.title: Reboot Needed?

panels.description: Tracks any updates that are available for your OS or for Rocket Pool but haven't been applied yet. When one of these numbers is higher than 0, it means you should update your system or Rocket Pool accordingly.
panels.title: Available Updates

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together

targets.expr: (((count(count(avg by (instance)(node_cpu_seconds_total{job="node"})) by (cpu))) - avg(avg by (instance)(irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode='idle',job="node"}[5m])))) * 100) / count(count(avg by (instance)(node_cpu_seconds_total{job="node"})) by (cpu))

panels.title: CPU Busy

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together (1 min average)
panels.title: CPU System Load (1m avg)

panels.description: Non available RAM memory
panels.title: Used RAM Memory

panels.description: The total amount of RAM that your system has installed.
panels.title: Total RAM

panels.description: The total amount of RAM that your system is currently using.
panels.title: Used RAM

panels.description: Used Swap
panels.title: Used SWAP

panels.description: Voters pending payout not yet staged
panels.title: Voters pending payout

panels.description: Delegate pending payout not yet staged
panels.title: Delegate pending payout

panels.description: Amount of coin in delegate wallet
panels.title: Delegate wallet balance

panels.description: Tracks the amount of CPU consumption for the eth2 client and the total system. 100% means all of your CPU core are being used at their full capacity. The yellow line indicates how much CPU a single core can provide in your system.
panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description: Tracks the total amount of RAM usage by the eth2 client and the entire system, versus how much is available.
panels.title: RAM Usage

panels.description: block number until your next payout.
panels.title: Block before payout

panels.description: Amount of staged payment
panels.title: Staged payout

panels.description: This tracks how long it takes between one of your processes trying to read from / write to your SSD, and when that operation is actually performed. Think of this like "how long SSD reads and writes have to wait in a queue before completing". The longer this time, the longer it takes for your node to perform its Beacon Chain duties.
panels.title: I/O Wait Time

panels.description: The disk space used by your primary (Operating System) hard drive. Change the `device` option in this query to be your machine's hard drive.
panels.title: OS Disk Space Used

panels.description: An optional space monitor for a second disk or partition on your system. If you store your chain data on a separate drive or partition from your OS (such as with a Raspberry Pi), you can configure this to track that disk. Just modify the `device` setting in the query with your storage partition's path.
panels.title: Disk 2 Space Used

panels.description: Total payed rewards
panels.title: Total distributed rewards

panels.description: The average read/write latency of your SSD. The lower it is, the faster your machine can process and respond to Beacon Chain activities like attesting. Change the `device` setting in the queries to be the SSD you want to track (typically the one with your chain data on it).
panels.title: SSD Latency

panels.description: A chart showing the network I/O used by your main network adapter over time. To make it work, change the `device` setting in the queries to match the name of the network adapter you want to track (you can use `ifconfig` to get a list of network adapters and find the right one).
panels.title: Network Usage

panels.description: The total network I/O that has gone through your main network adapter. To make it work, change the `device` setting in the queries to match the name of the network adapter you want to track (you can use `ifconfig` to get a list of network adapters and find the right one).
panels.title: Total Net I/O
